I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In response to requests from the Governments of Afghanistan and Tajikistan, the ADB is 
providing assistance to mitigate flooding and bank erosion on the Pyanj River. The Pyanj River 
is the source and primary tributary of the Amu Darya River. With the Pamir River, the Pyanj 
forms the international border between Afghanistan and Tajikistan. The Pyanj’s catchment area 
comprises 107,000 square kilometers (km2) of mountainous terrain that extends into a lowland 
flood plain of 6,500 km2. The Pyanj travels about 1,000 kilometers (km) before becoming the 
Amu Darya after the confluence of the Vache and Pamir rivers. More than 2,400 km long, with a 
basin of more than 530,000 km2, the Amu Darya is the largest river in Central Asia. The Amu 
Darya has annual flows of about 75 billion cubic meters, of which 13–18 billion cubic meters 
originates from Afghanistan, with the vast majority of the rest coming from Tajikistan.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Flood Risks. The Pyanj River poses significant flood and erosion risks to Afghanistan 
and Tajikistan. Although the risks differ for the two countries, they are an issue of significant 
mutual concern. The Afghan side of the border has many low-lying, densely populated islands in 
the delta as the river reaches the flood plain from the mountains. The soil is soft and very 
productive in the delta and along the Afghan bank, but few formal flood protection works have 
been  undertaken  in  Afghanistan.  Banks  erode  regularly,  especially  during  the  spring  and 
summer flood season, washing away settlements, traditional irrigation systems, and irrigated 
agricultural land. On the Tajik side, intensive irrigated agriculture was developed under the 
Soviet Union, and an extensive system of flood embankments was put in place to protect the 
irrigation systems. In the post-Soviet era, these defenses have deteriorated and erode during 
the flood season. When the embankments are breached, the flooding damages the irrigated 
agriculture and settlements that have developed behind their protection. 
 
3.  Constraints to Effective Flood Management. Effective flood management and the 
longer-term Pyanj River Basin development and management are constrained by (i) incomplete 
knowledge and understanding of the hydrology; (ii) lack of understanding of the Pyanj River 
morphology; (iii) lack of modes or institutions to effectively coordinate a joint approach to basin 
planning, development, and management; and (iv) lack of capacity to undertake the requisite 
activities for basin planning, development, and management. 
 
4.  Hydrometeorological monitoring and data within the basin are inadequate; in the Afghan 
portion of the basin, they have been essentially nonexistent since 1980. The Tajikistan Agency 
for Hydrometeorology in the Ministry of Agriculture and Nature Projection inherited the Soviet 
hydrometeorology system. However, the facilities have become increasingly dilapidated since 
the early 1990s. Tajikistan operates four gauging stations on the Pyanj River at Ishkashim, 
Shidz, Khirmanjo, and Nizhni Pyanj. However, river flow cannot be measured because the 
required cableways to the Afghan side are not functional due to lack of maintenance and 
security issues. Additional weather stations to assess snow pack and precipitation are needed. 
This information, essential for predicting flow, will become increasingly important with climate 
change. In addition to equipment, Afghanistan and Tajikistan must share information, which 
requires common protocols for data collection and analysis. Staff at the Ministry of Energy and 
Water (MEW) in Afghanistan and the Ministry of Water Resources and Land Reclamation 
(MWRLR)  in  Tajikistan  needs  substantial  capacity  development  for  more  effective  water 
management of the Pyanj. Establishing an extensive and reliable hydrometeorological network 
is critical for all aspects of basin planning, development, and management, including flood 
control, irrigation, hydropower, water supply, and environment.

2   
 
5.  The Pyanj River morphology is very dynamic, significantly increasing the difficulty of 
predicting floods, and designing and placing flood management infrastructure. This also has had 
implications for the location of the international border. Afghanistan has had numerous border 
treaties with its northern neighbors. The last one, signed with the Soviet Union in 1983, was 
based on the main river channel at that time. Since then, however, the main river channel has 
migrated north, well within Tajikistan, and runs nearly adjacent to the first 12 km of flood 
embankments downstream from the main irrigation intake on the Tajik side of the flood area.  In 
practice, Afghanistan is accustomed to occupying all of the territory to the south of this channel, 
meaning Afghans are on the Tajik side of the border. While the two countries have talked 
amicably to address this issue, significant further dialogue is needed to reach an agreement on 
border concerns. Extensive cooperation and data sharing are also required for both counties to 
develop and implement effective flood management. 
 
6.  Development Concerns.  In addition to the immediate concern over flood management, 
significant  development  opportunities  exist  in  the  Pyanj  River  Basin.  An  estimated  19,000 
megawatts of hydropower potential could be exploited, although only a small fraction has been 
developed. The Amu Darya supports 4 million hectares of irrigated agriculture, but additional 
land could be cultivated. Afghanistan, which has very limited development exploiting the Pyanj 
River  waters,  has  plans  to  expand  irrigated  area  and  develop  hydropower  in  the  basin. 
Tajikistan also has development plans, primarily hydropower, for the basin. While many of these 
opportunities  will  be  exploited  in due  time,  their  successful  development  will require  more 
knowledge  and  cooperation  between  Afghanistan  and  Tajikistan,  as  well  as  with  their 
downstream neighbors in accordance with international best practice and law.2 
 
7.  Existing Cooperation.  Afghanistan and Tajikistan have engaged in amicable dialogue 
and have demonstrated a willingness to work together, as expressed through the following: (i) 
cooperation agreement on the reclamation of hydropower resources of the Pyanj River (April 
2005), (ii) memorandum of understanding between MEW and MWRLR (September 2006), (iii) 
agreement between the governments on mutual cooperation on transboundary river use and 
protection  (2007),  (iv)  minutes  of  the  joint  meeting  of  delegations  from  Tajikistan  and 
Afghanistan  concerning  bank  strengthening  works  on  the  Pyanj  River  (March  2007),  (v) 
strengthening transboundary cooperation in water resources management between Afghanistan 
and Tajikistan in the Upper Amu Darya River Basin (Northern Atlantic Treaty Organization – 
Environment and Security Initiative) (April 2007), and (vi) a recent mission by Afghan officials to 
Dushanbe in August 2007. Despite the dialogue and missions, most of the agreements are 
general  with  few  specific  actions,  and  all  activities  have  been  on  an  ad  hoc  basis.  More 
substantive and permanent engagement is needed to address issues of common concern to 
Afghanistan and Tajikistan in the Pyanj River Basin. 
 
8.  Asian Development Bank (ADB) Assistance.  ADB has recently provided assistance 
to Tajikistan to address flood concerns through changes in scope to an agriculture rehabilitation 
loan and an irrigation rehabilitation loan to rebuild the embankments that were destroyed in the 
floods in 2005. ADB also recently approved the Khatlon Province Flood Risk Management 
Project3 ($23 million) to finish the rehabilitation of the embankments, which will be implemented 
by MWRLR. Some of these actions have raised Afghan concerns that reinforcing the flood

protection works on the Tajik side of the river will exacerbate flood and erosion problems on the 
Afghan side. However, the environmental assessments carried out under ADB projects have not 
substantiated  these  concerns.  Still,  the  damage  on  the  Afghan  side  is  substantial  and  of 
paramount concern to the Government of Afghanistan. ADB is responding to these concerns 
through a proposed $3 million grant from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) for the 
Community Flood Management and Livelihood Protection Project in Takhar Province, which will 
provide livelihood development in affected areas and civil works for riverbank protection. In 
addition, the Afghanistan Water Resources Development Project, ADB’s proposed next water 
resources grant to Afghanistan for approximately $200 million in 2009, has a large component 
proposed for extensive flood protection works along the Pyanj and Amu Darya rivers. 
 
9.  The  Way  Forward.  However,  to  address  flood  issues  effectively  and  sustainably 
throughout the Pyanj River Basin, a more comprehensive and methodical approach is needed. 
This requires Afghanistan and Tajikistan to work jointly on a plan to (i) improve river flow and 
flood prediction ability; (ii) identify, evaluate, prioritize, and program structural and nonstructural 
flood  management  measures;  and  (iii)  strengthen  flood  warning  and  emergency  response 
capacity. While flood management is of immediate concern, it is a subset of overall river basin 
planning, development, and management, which is the appropriate framework in which it should 
be addressed. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the regional technical assistance (RETA) will be improved water resources 
management in the Pyanj River Basin, and the immediate reduction of negative impacts from 
floods and bank erosion. The RETA outcome will be improved knowledge, increased capacity, 
and strengthened institutions for planning and managing the Pyanj River Basin with a focus on 
flood management. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The RETA will have the following components: (i) improved knowledge base for basin 
planning, development, and management; (ii) flood management; (iii) institutional development 
and cooperation; and (iv) capacity building supported through execution of relevant outputs. 
 
12.  Improved Knowledge Base for Basin Planning, Development, and Management. 
This component will develop a program to compile and manage technical and socioeconomic 
information to support immediate efforts to improve flood management. The information and its 
ongoing management also will support broader planning and management activities throughout 
the Amu Darya Basin. The approach to this component will be to coordinate ongoing activities of 
the governments, development partners, and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) in the 
basin. It will also directly support initial studies that address critical data gaps, focusing on 
hydrology, the hydrometeorology network, river morphology, and social and economic baseline 
data. Outputs from this component will include an overall assessment of needs and plan for 
basin  data  collection  and  management,  management  information  systems,  geographic 
information systems management tools, protocols for data sharing, and selected studies. 
 
13.  Flood Management. This component will have three subcomponents: (i) improving river 
flow and flood prediction capacity for the Pyanj; (ii) identifying, screening, and prioritizing a 
program of structural and nonstructural, mutually beneficial flood management measures for 
Afghanistan and Tajikistan; and (iii) strengthening the flood warning and emergency response 
capacity for both countries. This component will build upon the work of the first component. As 
envisaged, some of the high-priority flood management measures identified will be developed

4   
further and supported by ADB financing under the proposed Afghanistan Water Resources 
Management Project in 2009.4 Outputs from this component will include analyses of hydrology 
and morphology, institutional assessments of flood-related agencies, scoping, pre-feasibility and 
feasibility studies for flood management, flood and hazard mapping, and plans to improve flood 
management and response. The RETA will produce a Pyanj River Basin flood management 
master plan that covers Tajikistan and Afghanistan.5 For the first two components, a technical 
secretariat will be created with MEW and MWRLR staff and other relevant ministries to work 
with the implementation consultants. 
 
14.  Institutional Development and Cooperation. This component will foster cooperation 
on various levels. It will support the establishment and regular meetings of a steering committee 
that will set the agenda and guide the RETA, as well as serve as a permanent platform for 
Afghanistan and Tajikistan to discuss issues of mutual concern in the Pyanj River Basin. If the 
governments want a permanent management organization for Pyanj River Basin, the RETA 
team will work with the steering committee to develop one. Importantly, the steering committee 
will provide a forum to coordinate and communicate progress and concerns regarding ADB 
activities in the area, including (i) the Khatlon Province Flood Risk Management Project, (ii) the 
proposed  JFPR  Community  Flood  Management  and  Livelihood  Protection  Project  in 
Afghanistan, and (iii) the proposed Afghanistan Water Resources Management Project for 2009. 
In addition to flood management, the steering committee will address other issues of mutual 
concern,  such  as  reconciliation  of  the  international  boundary.  This  component  will  provide 
needed technical and/or legal and institutional expertise to support the development of bilateral 
agreements for planning, development, and management in the Pyanj River Basin. Initially, it 
will focus on the requisite agreements to support the development of the flood master plan. This 
component also will support facilitation of meetings and any required institutional and other 
expertise to support the work of the steering committee. Further, it will facilitate community 
exchanges of local residents and local government officials to work on the flood master plan, 
coordinate flood emergency response efforts, and execute other aspects of the RETA. Standing 
or ad hoc committees will be formed as needed while the work progresses. Outputs from this 
component  will  include  agreements,  meeting  minutes,  special  studies,  and  policy 
recommendations. 
 
15.  Capacity Development.  Capacity development cuts across all aspects of the RETA 
and will be delivered through a variety of methods. The technical secretariat will work closely 
with the technical specialists recruited through the RETA, who will provide workshops, short 
training courses, and resource materials for the relevant agencies and communities in both 
countries. Outside training and short courses also will be provided to the technical secretariat. 
The RETA team will coordinate relevant training with ongoing ADB interventions in Afghanistan 
and Tajikistan, such as the Khatlon Province Flood Risk Management Project and the proposed 
Afghanistan Water Resources Management Project. Further, the RETA will support training for 
the steering committee and fund its members’ participation in conferences and other activities 
related to basin planning, management, and development. Outputs from this component will 
include resource materials, workshops, short training courses, and reports. 
                                                 
4 The RETA will carry out required due diligence on the environment, indigenous peoples, and resettlement according 
to ADB’s guidelines. The RETA will not support civil works. The majority of safeguard due diligence will be 
executed when feasibility studies and detailed designs are finalized under subsequent investments. 
5 The flood master plan will include screening criteria such as technical, social, economic, and environmental 
considerations for proposed interventions. It also will explore financing options for its implementation.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The RETA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $1.7 million, of which $1.6 million will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s technical assistance funding program. The governments will 
contribute a local currency cost equivalent to $100,000 on a pro rata basis. Detailed cost estimates 
and financing are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA. MEW and MWRLR will be the lead 
counterpart  agencies.  At  RETA  inception,  ADB  in  consultation  with  the  governments  will 
establish the steering committee comprising ministerial-level officials from MEW, MWRLR, and 
other federal ministries, as well as senior local officials in the Pyanj River Basin. The steering 
committee, which will be responsible for RETA oversight, will meet as needed, but at least three 
times per year. A technical secretariat with representatives primarily from MEW and MWRLR 
will be established to support the work of the RETA and the steering committee. The secretariat, 
which will serve as the project management unit, will work closely with the technical specialists 
recruited through the RETA and the steering committee to execute RETA activities. Local 
officials are also expected to be a part of the technical secretariat and support efforts to improve 
flood warning, preparedness, and emergency response activities. The secretariat’s composition 
will be confirmed at RETA inception, but it will include a project director from each country. The 
technical secretariat will work full time to support RETA activities, and will operate as required in 
Dushanbe,  Kabul,  and  the  field.  Standing  or  ad  hoc  committees  to  facilitate  community 
exchanges  will  be  established  to  support  work  under  the  RETA  and  facilitate  greater 
cooperation in flood management efforts. In addition, the governments will provide access to 
office space in Dushanbe, Kabul, and the field, as required; access to telephones and utilities; 
and logistical support. The activities will be executed over 30 months beginning in the first 
quarter of 2008.  
 
18.  The RETA will finance 40 person-months of international and 94 person-months of 
national consulting input in water resources management, hydrology, hydrometeorology, flood 
management engineering, geographic information systems, financial and economic analysis, 
social assessment, and environment. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. ADB will 
engage the consultants under the RETA in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time), using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method  through  a  simplified  technical  proposal.  Suitably  qualified  NGOs,  other  firms,  or 
individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  as  needed  to  assist  with  necessary  community 
engagement, as well as for other technical studies and services. No activities will commence 
under this RETA until a letter of no-objection has been received by ADB from the Governments 
of Afghanistan and Tajikistan. 
 
19.  Operating in Afghanistan presents security challenges. The RETA team will work closely 
with the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan, the Government, and the ADB 
security advisor to develop a security plan for RETA execution. The RETA will contract local 
NGOs  that  are  well  established  in  the  area  to  deliver  services  and  facilitate  community 
interaction  with  RETA  technical  specialists  and  other  RETA  staff.  Technical  work  can  be 
conducted from the Tajik side with limited exposure to the Afghan side. However, the two 
governments should be equally engaged. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $1,600,000 on a grant basis to the governments of Afghanistan 
and Tajikistan for the Pyanj River Basin Flood Management Project.

12         Appendix 3 
 
(xv)  in cooperation with the hydrologist and hydrometeorological specialist, recommend 
any necessary improvements to the hydrologic monitoring networks and telemetry 
systems in the Pyanj River Basin to facilitate timely flood forecasts and warnings for 
flood risk areas in the flood plain;  
(xvi)  in cooperation with the hydrologist and hydrometeorological specialist, assess the 
scope for mathematical modeling of the Pyanj River by statistical, hydrologic routing, 
or hydraulic routing techniques to replicate historic flood levels and simulate design 
flood levels relative to variations in assumed return periods;  
(xvii)  participate in the delineation of flood risk areas on flood risk maps in terms of the 
frequency and/or probability of flooding and impacts on the assets in the flood risk 
areas;  
(xviii)  review  existing  and  planned  arrangements  for  flood  preparedness  in  terms  of 
prepared  evacuation  plans;  and  the  readiness  of  emergency  services  and 
communities with respect to materials, transport, training, drills, flood watch schemes, 
and communications;  
(xix)  assess past performance of flood preparedness systems, identify weaknesses, and 
recommend improvements;  
(xx)  oversee assessments of agencies and their capacities and recommend ways to 
improve flood warning, management, and preparedness, including the ability to deal 
with social issues;  
(xxi)  present objectives, principles, and priorities of a draft flood management master plan 
to governments and other stakeholders; and  
(xxii)  based on seminar commentary, prepare a final flood management master plan for 
the project areas, including flood warning and flood prevention, and structural and 
nonstructural flood management components. 
 
3.  Hydrologists  and  Hydrometeorology  Specialist  (international,  5  person-months; 
Afghan, 5 person-months; Tajik, 5 person-months). The hydrologists and hydrometeorology 
specialists will  
(i)  review hydrological records and trends, and causes of the historic floods;  
(ii)  estimate design river flood levels in the project area for a range of flood return 
periods;  
(iii)  interpret the hydrological data and assist extensively in preparation of flood risk 
maps;  
(iv)  recommend  improvements  in  and  coordination  of  routine  hydrometeorological 
monitoring and data management in Afghanistan and Tajikistan;  
(v)  formulate  special  monitoring  of  unique  flood  hazards,  e.g.,  glacial  lake  outburst 
floods;  
(vi)  review hydrometeorological monitoring and data management in the Pyanj River 
Basin, and the dissemination of flood warning and preparedness warnings;  
(vii)  identify  deficiencies  and  disparities  between  the  operational,  maintenance,  and 
institutional arrangements prevalent in Afghanistan and Tajikistan; and  
(viii)  prepare a detailed plan for additional or upgraded equipment, institutional capacity 
building,  and  coordination  of  equipment,  convergence  of  procedures,  and  data 
dissemination systems, including telemetry, between the two countries. 
 
4.  River Morphologists (international, 4 person-months; Afghan, 4 person-months; Tajik, 
4 person-months). The river morphologists will (i) analyze historic trends in the river before and 
after construction of embankments using available historic and current maps, satellite imagery, 
and local information; (ii) assess the extent, if any, that flood embankments have contributed to 
changes in river morphology, and estimate the scale of future changes that flood defense

Appendix 3  13 
improvements might bring; (iii) consider alternative layouts for future flood embankments; and 
(iv) define appropriate floodways through application modeling techniques. 
 
5.  Environment Specialists (international, 2 person-months; Afghan, 2 person-months; 
Tajik, 2 person-months). The environment specialists will  
(i)  assess the likely impacts of the proposed structural flood defensive measures in 
Pyanj  River  flood  plain  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines  (2003),  and  Afghanistan’s  and  Tajikistan’s  national  environmental 
regulations;  
(ii)  if required, prepare a draft initial environmental examination for sample subprojects 
and measures under the proposed flood management master plan;  
(iii)  facilitate public awareness consultations in the project area on the findings of the 
initial environmental examination;  
(iv)  define the extent and significance of any environmental impacts in Afghanistan and 
Tajikistan, as well as downstream in Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan;  
(v)  recommend  draft  environmental  management  plans  for  the  implementation  of 
structural  flood  management  measures  components  of  the  proposed  flood 
management master plan, including an assessment of the institutional capacity to 
monitor compliance, and a delineation of ongoing and/or continuing supplementary 
programs; and  
(vi)  develop  environmental  assessment  and  review  procedures  to  be  used  during 
implementation of the flood management master plan. 
 
6.  Social  Assessment  and  Resettlement  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months; 
Afghan, 3 person-months; Tajik, 3 person-months). The social assessment and resettlement 
specialist will  
(i)  design, commission, and supervise social surveys of the communities in the flood 
plain  of  the  Pyanj  River  in  Afghanistan  and  Tajikistan  to  determine  the 
socioeconomic impact of floods;  
(ii)  analyze the socioeconomic data to determine the vulnerabilities of communities to 
floods with particular attention to the poor and women householders, and general 
attention to the willingness to participate in community-based flood management 
schemes,  such  as  voluntary  workforces,  local  flood  warning  schemes,  and 
management of riparian land;  
(iii)  draft a poverty and social analysis for inclusion in the Report and Recommendation 
of the President;  
(iv)  undertake an preliminary assessment of possible social impacts of the proposed 
flood  management  project,  and  address  any  issues  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995);  
(v)  develop detailed terms of reference for resettlement activities to be prepared in 
conjunction  with  proposed  investment  following  implementation  of  the  flood 
management master plan;  
(vi)  organize  stakeholder  consultations  to  ensure  that  relevant  social  aspects  are 
incorporated  into  local  flood  preparedness  plans  and  response  mechanisms,  in 
particular responding to the additional burdens placed on women during floods;  
(vii)  review the capacity of community groups to implement flood mitigation measures; 
and  
(viii)  assess the prevalence of indigenous peoples in the Pyanj River Basin, and identify 
any relevant issues for further analysis that might affect indigenous peoples under 
future flood management efforts.

Appendix 3            14          
 
7.  Geographic  Information  System  (GIS)  Specialist  (international,  4 person-months, 
Afghan, 4 person-months; Tajik, 4 person-months). The GIS specialist will  
(i)  review  the  availability  of  maps,  satellite  imagery,  aerial  photography,  and 
cartographic data depicting the Pyanj River Basin in Afghanistan and Tajikistan;  
(ii)  design topographic survey programs to update and fill gaps in existing base mapping 
at scales suitable for use in HEC-RAS or similar modeling;  
(iii)  establish a GIS database for the Pyanj River Basin based on existing data and new 
data prepared under the RETA;  
(iv)  develop and confirm GIS maps, and support for other staff at the local and basin-
wide levels;  
(v)  provide on-the-job and higher level training for counterpart staff to support the RETA 
and the staff of the Ministry of Energy and Water and Ministry of Water Resources 
and Land Reclamation; and  
(vi)  develop management information systems and analytical tools based on GIS and 
other programs, such as land use mapping in cooperation with the Ministry of Energy 
and Water, Ministry of Water Resources and Land Reclamation, and other relevant 
agencies. 
 
8.  Economist and Financial Analysis Specialist (international, 2 person-months; Afghan, 
2 person-months; Tajik, 2 person-months). The economist and financial analysis specialist will  
(i)  in conjunction with the engineers and social assessment and resettlement specialist, 
develop  estimates  of  costs  and  benefits  (quantifiable  and  nonquantifiable)  for 
financial and economic analysis of various flood management options under the 
flood management master plan;  
(ii)  support the RETA team in providing costs estimates for various flood mitigation 
options as a part of the flood management master plan;  
(iii)  based on the financial and economic analysis, support prioritization of the measures 
to be pursued under the flood management master plan;  
(iv)  assess the potential poverty reduction impact of the project and likely distribution of 
benefits;  
(v)  identify the economic risks associated with the project;  
(vi)  assist the RETA team in defining the O&M costs for various options under the flood 
management master plan, and help to identify sustainable measures for financing 
O&M;  
(vii)  assess the financial implications of various options of the flood management master 
plan on the budgets of the relevant government departments in Afghanistan and 
Tajikistan, and estimate the incremental budgetary provisions required to maintain 
the proposed flood management assets in each country;  
(viii)  explore financing options for the flood management master plan; and  
(ix)  review the financial management functions and auditing practices of the relevant 
government departments in Afghanistan and Tajikistan, and recommend financial 
management measures to reduce risks of mismanagement. 
 
9.  Unallocated (international, 2 person-months; Afghan, 5 person-months; Tajik, 5 person-
months).  These  unallocated  months  are  to  extend  the  inputs  of  the  existing  RETA  team 
specialists if needed or for the services new specialists whose need may arise during the course 
of the RETA.
